topic.title: What happens if I modify my version of a zite?
topic.body:
I hope there is a mechanism to prevent anybody from editing websites they are seeding in a way that'd influence the other versions of the zite, but I'd like to know for sure and also how it works.

Example: Because I'm browsing 0talk, I have a local folder containing the files. When I click Add new topic, this local data is changed and the change is sent to all others, so that the zite contains my post, even if I'm offline. But what if I replaced the "Add new topic" Button functionality with malicious code? Would that be shared on to others?

I know, the mentality should be the key to a working network like this, but just because we should and maybe can rely on peole's morals when everything is so easily hackable that nobody gets a sense of accomplishment of doing it, I find we should have at least some security measurements. Is there for example a way to define code that can never be changed when I create a zite?
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Also, as I'm kinda new here, how does publishing new stuff to a zite work? Maybe the answer is the same. Do changes have to be signed to be accepted or something like that?

1_17M2Zwbk1drijqtf94fDyBGm7XucVrYPFC.body: whoa how did this text become bold?

> [kindlyfire](#comment_21_1FTFKztuv4Z5uy6iS83k9hB2xtS6yFnDxx): If you modify a zite's code, you won't be able to seed the files you edited, because it doesn't match what the original author signed. The only way to modify a zite and send it to every peer is to sign it with the zite's private key.

Alright, thanks :)
How does stuff like posting here work then? it also changes content.

> [kindlyfire](#comment_22_1FTFKztuv4Z5uy6iS83k9hB2xtS6yFnDxx): It doesn't actually change the site's source code itself. When this site's author made the zite, he specified that every user id (mine is kindlyfire@zeroid.bit per example) can have it's own directory. You and the admin are the only persons who can write in that directory. The admin can also specify a maximum size, which is 40K here.
> When a users opens the zite, ZeroNet will build a database containing everything in every user's directory. That way, if you publish content in your directory, it will get published in everybody's local database. But: you can only edit your own directory, not the one of somebody else.
> Hope that clears some things up :) docs need some clearing up on that too.

thanks :)
